intro: Phaeanthus ebracteolatus, commonly known as the narrow-leaved phaeanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic compounds. The plant features narrow, lance-shaped leaves and small, clustered white or greenish flowers. It typically grows in moist, sandy soils along stream banks and in open woodlands. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
